27.17.text:
People who make it out of groups like exploitative
religious and pseudoscientific organisations

33.62.text: are often faced with distortions from two directions.

36.54.text:
When they attempt to convey their experiences
of manipulation to members of their former group

40.52.text:
their words are magically transformed
into 'I'm mad, evil and weak'.

45.24.text:
But when they share their story 
with non-members as a cautionary tale

48.78.text:
their words are often magically transformed into
'I'm gullible, asinine and spineless'.

54.46.text:
After a while, the apostates realise
they're in the noonesland of the unheard.

58.30.text:
And it begins to become clear
why these groups continue to thrive —

61.74.text: groups with a talent for bending truth,

63.96.text:
preaching love while denouncing
non-members as a subhuman underclass;

67.82.text:
claiming to champion peace,
while committing acts of barbarism;

71.52.text:
pontificating about family values while
tearing up countless homes;

75.42.text:
promising freedom and enlightenment while
enforcing ignorance and exercising total control

81.56.text:
I want to explore some of
the mechanics of manipulative groups,

84.60.text:
dispatching some of the stereotypes
about the people who get recruited by them,

88.16.text:
and reflecting on preventive measures
we might take to avoid recruitment.

92.00.text:
But if there's just one thing
I really want to do in this video,

95.46.text:
it's to communicate the importance of
acknowledging a simple but profound fact:

108.04.text: At a press conference on manipulative groups

110.62.text: Ian reveals he lost tens of thousands of dollars

112.78.text: When he was recruited by a group who proposed that

115.18.text:
clusters of alien spirits are attached
to all humans, keeping us from a full potential.

119.80.text:
Ian tells us how he and the other group members
paid through the nose — and every other orifice —

124.98.text:
for a special kind of counselling which they
were told would rid them of these spirits.

129.34.text:
They were told that once these spirits were gone,
they would be the primary causal agents of their lives

134.26.text:
with skills such as telekinesis, total recall
and mastery over illness.

138.96.text: No evidence was given for any of this.

141.06.text:
The alien story was the unsubstantiated
revelation claim of the group's founder

144.88.text:
and no records have ever been
produced of a single person

147.66.text:
gaining any of the special powers
or knowledge described.

150.84.text: What do we think of Ian?

154.92.text: No. His intelligence is above average.

157.50.text:
He's a highly creative, resourceful man — that's why
the group considered him such a juicy prospect.

162.78.text:
Is he a bit credulous —
quick to accept whatever he's told?

166.38.text: No. In fact, by default, he's a cautious skeptical fellow.

170.56.text:
Is he driven by narcissism,
desiring supremacy over others?

174.56.text:
No. He's always been compelled
by deeply humanitarian instincts.

178.48.text: Of course there are folks out there who are ....

180.72.text:
gullible, obtuse, submissive,
power-hungry, escapist, lazy.

186.26.text: But it's a huge mistake to assume that

188.26.text:
successful recruitment into manipulative groups
depends on the presence of these kinds of traits.

193.38.text:
And while we're hunting for them in Ian's case,
we're missing six crucial words:

199.68.text: He was subjected to a process.

201.84.text:
The idea of alien spirit clusters wasn't presented
to him in the bald way he presented it to us.

206.78.text:
Ian was carefully steered
through a sequence of experiences

210.06.text:
so that by the time the alien
spirits concept was mentioned

212.92.text:
a range of key psychological elements had
been established

215.90.text: to ease its entry and help insulate it from criticism.

219.38.text: Later on, I'll be looking at how this was done.

222.08.text:
Just as we can become distracted
by the red herring of personality deficiencies

226.10.text:
we can become misled by the notion
of predisposing circumstance.

229.72.text:
Some psychologists have generated
lists of situational factors

232.92.text: that can leave us vulnerable to manipulative groups.

235.50.text:
Factors like 'weak family bonds'
or 'recent bereavement'.

240.04.text:
Problem is, when we don't find
ourselves reflected in those items,

243.60.text: we can be left with the impression we're not vulnerable.

246.32.text: When we see an item like 'weak family bonds'

248.86.text: we might satisfy ourselves that we not risk

251.38.text: because we have strong family bonds.

253.52.text: But strong family bonds can put people at risk too.

256.38.text: Many people are recruited by relative.

258.62.text: And if your whole family's been indoctrinated,

260.74.text: you could be born into a manipulative group.

262.98.text:
In these cases, even if you wake up
and smell the Kool Aid

266.12.text:
strong family bonds might keep you
feeling trapped inside the group

269.22.text: under the threat of disconnection from your family.

272.18.text:
Members of manipulative groups are a
diverse population

275.62.text: and it serves us well to think creatively

278.40.text: about how these groups might hook us in.

286.64.text:
Some of us go through life convinced we
possess an almost clinical objectivity —

290.92.text:
that, barring deliberate deceptions or the
odd quirky optical illusion,

295.30.text:
we generally perceived reality as it actually is;
and that we make decisions on a firmly rational basis.

301.60.text:
For over a century, social psychologists
 have been ripping that fantasy apart,

306.28.text:
conducting experiments that elicit the most bizarre,
counterintuitive human responses

310.76.text: and exposing a gamut of distinct biases

313.56.text:
each of which distorts our perception
in its own specific way.

317.40.text:
A landmark concept in social psychology 
emerged in the 1950s

321.28.text:
that provided a framework on which to untangle
all kinds of paradoxical human behaviour.

326.02.text: Leon Festinger's theory of cognitive dissonance.

328.98.text:
It also described arguably the biggest implement
in the toolboxes of manipulative groups

333.86.text:
who not only rely on it to keep
existing members under their influence

337.24.text: but also actively exploit it to recruit new members.

340.76.text:
Festinger and his colleagues proposed that
 we seek consistency within our cognitions —

348.49.text:
and that when we discover an inconsistency
we experience a psychological discomfort

353.08.text: that motivates us to try and reduce that conflict.

355.90.text: So, what does dissonance look like in action?

358.46.text:
Say we've been told to believe
all members of group A evil.

362.20.text:
One day, a friend we've always known to be
a good person reveals she's a member of group A.

366.88.text:
This arouses dissonance because
our experience contradicts our belief.

370.62.text: We can reduce this dissonance in a number of ways.

372.98.text:
If we're not hugely invested in the belief,
we might opt for method one:

378.24.text:
We might, for instance, change it to:
'not all members of group A are evil'.

382.54.text:
If we're equally invested
in the belief and the friendship

385.32.text: we might try to preserve both using method two: denial.

389.02.text:
We might refuse to believe
our friend is a true member of group A,

392.26.text:
granting her special exemption
because she's just not like those other folks.

396.20.text:
If we're more invested in the belief than
the friendship, we might go for method three:

402.34.text:
Here, we cherry-pick information consistent with
our belief and ignore information that contradicts it.

407.12.text:
Any flaws in our friend's behaviour
or attitudes can be turned against her

413.16.text:
Festinger and his colleagues noted
that when we experience dissonance

416.46.text:
we'll tend to avoid information or situations
that threaten further dissonance.

420.82.text:
For instance, if we've denied that
our friend is a member of group A,

424.42.text: we'll want to avoid the subject in future conversations.

427.44.text:
Or, if we've used selective information
to cast our friend as evil,

431.38.text:
we might quickly break off contact to avoid
giving her the chance to reason with us.

436.16.text:
But sometimes our response to dissonance
is so horrendously distorted

440.10.text:
that it makes us almost
invulnerable to further dissonance,

445.26.text:
For example, say we look for evidence
that our friend's evil, but can't find any?

449.98.text: What if — time after time — we're confronted with good?

453.42.text:
How can we possibly preserve a belief
that all members of group A are evil now?

457.40.text: Well, all is not as bleak as it seems.

462.56.text:
Believing that no member of
group A could possibly be good

465.40.text:
We could repackage our experience 
of our friend's goodness as something it's not.

469.34.text:
We might tell ourselves she was only pretending
to be good — it was all an act, a deception.

474.36.text: And isn't that the most insidious evil of all?

476.78.text: The evil that disguises itself as good?

481.10.text: We've now put our friend in a no-win position.

483.82.text:
Even her goodness has now
become evidence of her evil.

486.90.text: Now we don't even have to avoid her.

488.78.text: Anything she does — good or bad — confirms our belief.

492.74.text:
Later on, I'll be looking at how manipulative groups
explicitly employ these kinds of extreme contortions

498.06.text: to put their critics in a no-win position

500.36.text: and keep their members under psychological lockdown.

503.64.text:
Various experiments have shown how dissonance
can be actively exploited to induce positive responses.

510.48.text:
Aronson and Mills investigated the role of initiation
procedures in attitudes toward groups.

515.52.text:
They advertised for female subjects to join
a group discussing the psychology of sex.

520.22.text:
But before being accepted, subjects were told
they had to pass an embarrassment test.

528.94.text:
read out loud to the experimenter
a list of words considered obscene

532.48.text: as well as sexually explicit passages.

534.88.text: Subjects in the 'mild initiation' condition read out loud a list of sexual but non-obscene terms.

540.02.text: Subjects in the 'no initiation' condition weren't screened.

543.60.text:
Each subject then listened to the same pre-recorded
discussion, deliberately designed to be boring.

548.92.text: They then rated their perceptions of the group.

551.30.text: Intuitively, one might think the more severe the initiation

554.82.text:
the more the discussion's
dreariness would be accentuated.

559.56.text:
Subjects from the 'severe' condition showed
the strongest liking for the group,

563.16.text:
rating it as significantly more attractive
compared with the ratings of the other groups.

567.56.text: Aronson and Mills explained this counter-intuitive finding in terms of dissonance between two cognitions:

573.38.text: subjects in the 'severe' condition had gone through a difficult experience to join the group,

579.92.text:
When we invest time, effort, money,
emotion, in an enterprise

584.32.text: we want to believe our investment isn't wasted.

586.92.text: So we repackage useless enterprises as useful.

591.04.text: This result, supported by other studies,

593.32.text:
demonstrates how worthless groups
can be made to appear worthwhile.

597.16.text:
A decade later, Knox and Inkster showed
just how quickly actions can induce attitudes.

602.66.text:
At a racetrack, 69 bettors were asked
by one experimenter, just prior to betting

607.76.text: to rate the chances of their horse winning.

609.90.text:
72 bettors were asked by a second
experimenter, just after placing their bets.

614.50.text:
Using a 7-point scale, on average,
pre-bettors rated their chances 'fair'.

622.22.text:
One bettor, who'd given a rating
to the pre-bet experimenter and placed his bet

626.44.text:
then spotted the post-bet experimenter
and asked if the two were working together.

630.90.text:
He then enquired if he could now
change his rating from 'fair' to 'excellent'.

634.93.text:
Studies like this show the important
role behaviour plays in dissonance.

638.41.text:
In fact, when we're looking at the
components of dissonance

641.39.text:
we could divide them into three broad classes:
behaviour, emotions and thoughts.

647.29.text:
Pull hard enough on one and, in our drive
for consistency, the others will follow

651.93.text:
When we behave as if we're committed,
our thoughts and emotions often fall in line.

656.60.text:
But how do we become
so heavily invested in an idea

659.70.text:
that we find ourselves twisting
concepts into their opposites —

662.78.text:
bending 'good' into 'evil', 'love' into 'hate' —
just to preserve that idea?

667.54.text:
While cognitive dissonance studies tend
to focus on the conflict between two ideas

671.66.text: those two ideas don't of course exist in isolation.

674.58.text: Networks of reinforcing ideas often lie behind them.

677.60.text:
For instance, regarding our
hypothetical belief that group A is evil

681.38.text:
maybe our entire community has
always vehemently condemned group A.

685.68.text:
We might have behaved hatefully toward some
members of group A ourselves in the past

692.08.text:
We might also have seen group A sympathisers
being attacked and ostracised.

696.50.text:
If it turns out group A isn't evil,
we have some tough realities to face.

700.96.text:
First, we have to admit
our entire community is wrong.

704.35.text:
This could tap into some hefty issues
around trust, loyalty and credibility.

709.22.text:
Second, we'll have to admit our own
hateful behaviour was unjustified.

712.94.text: This could have big implications for our self-image.

716.38.text:
Third, we now face being attacked
and ostracised if we defend groups A

720.38.text: which taps into our ideas of safety and security.

723.68.text:
These tough realities might
feel intensely threatening to us.

727.24.text:
But the threat goes away if we can find some way
of preserving our belief that group A is evil.

732.14.text:
So it is that we might find ourselves turning on
our friend just to preserve a false belief.

737.08.text:
And of course this might in itself make it even harder
to admit our mistake in the future

741.76.text: because adding to all the other tough realities

743.92.text: we'll now have to admit we betrayed a good friend.

747.36.text: Our minds are not objective, logical machines.

751.04.text:
Our minds of vast networks of ideas,
striving not necessarily for truth

757.67.text:
In view of this, it's plain to see why childhood
is by far the most preferred period

764.10.text:
Parents and guardians can
get in there right at the start

766.88.text: and insert any unsubstantiated concept they like

769.38.text:
into the child's basic
initial framework without resistance.

775.24.text: they stand a good chance of becoming core beliefs

777.56.text:
with rich networks of ideas reinforcing them including
strong associations of identity of many levels —

787.86.text:
If the unsubstantiated concept is later challenged,
threatening tremors could be felt in all of these areas.

793.42.text:
Indoctrinating adults who've already developed
an advanced cognitive network isn't so straightforward.

799.28.text:
Manipulative groups often have to
insert their unsubstantiated ideas

805.46.text: And it's no coincidence that in order to achieve that goal

808.64.text:
some groups will try to mimic those
childhood conditions by infantilising adults.

813.54.text:
When I was a christian we were repeatedly told
that we needed to be like children —

820.18.text: which in the total absence of any evidence of Yahweh

823.30.text:
translates to: 'trusting and dependent on
the humans who claim to represent Yahweh'.

827.94.text:
And there was a nice little threat
thrown in there.

830.38.text:
If you didn't become like children,
you'd never get into heaven.

833.40.text:
In a similar vein we were told:
'Lean not on your own understanding'.

837.24.text: 'Do not be wise in your own eyes'.

839.28.text:
The message in all these
commands couldn't be clearer.

842.08.text:
Wherever your ideas conflict with those of the group,
it's your ideas that need to change.

846.96.text: Folks who submit to these commands can now have vast amounts of their cognitive network rewritten

852.10.text: without substantial resistance — just like childhood.

855.16.text:
Of course, adult recruits are more of a bonus
than a necessity for the major world religions

859.64.text: who are guaranteed a steady influx of child recruits

862.66.text:
As long as the abuse of childhood
religious indoctrination continues.

866.60.text: Other groups who are more reliant on adult recruits

869.15.text:
often have to manipulate cognitive
dissonance in more subtle ways.

879.19.text: Let's go back to Ian and see how he gets recruited

882.23.text:
by a group claiming clusters of
alien spirits are attached to us all

885.73.text: keeping us from a full potential.

887.42.text:
Ian is approached on the street
by a woman with a personality questionnaire.

891.16.text:
He agrees to accompany her inside
the official promises behind her

894.32.text: where he spends half an hour completing it.

896.47.text:
His results show him to be
unstable, depressed, nervous and overly critical.

903.60.text: But the woman talks with him for a further half hour about his life — his frustrations, his disappointments —

909.20.text: and draws tentative connections with his results.

912.18.text:
She says her group runs courses that can
help him become a more effective person.

916.22.text:
Ian's natural caution stops him
from signing up for a course

919.18.text: but he agrees to buy a cheap book.

921.18.text:
He now experiences his first cognitive
dissonance in the group's favour.

924.96.text:
He has two conflicting cognitions:
one, that he's not interested;

928.88.text:
but two, that he's just invested an hour
of his time and bought a book.

933.04.text:
Dissonance leads him to adjust his first cognition
and rationalise that he is interested.

937.90.text:
Going home, he dips into the book and reflects on
the idea of becoming a more effective person.

942.50.text: The questionnaire results begin to play on his mind.

945.02.text:
Despite himself, he begins
to select confirming information

948.56.text: finding memories that match the results.

950.82.text:
Deciding he has nothing to lose by
giving it a go, he returns

954.02.text: and signs up for a course on communication.

956.66.text: Ian is now locked into a commitment cycle.

959.58.text:
The more time and money he invests,
the more he becomes convinced it's worthwhile

963.26.text:
The easier he's persuaded to invest
more time and money in further courses.

967.12.text:
The courses include odd activities like
sitting in silence, staring at another member

971.86.text: or endlessly picking up the same object.

977.28.text: And induce trance states and hallucinations

982.80.text:
At the end of each course Ian has to
write up and read out loud to the group

988.04.text:
This forces him not only to find meaning
in the meaningless tasks

993.54.text:
Declaring benefits he doesn't
really feel creates dissonance

996.52.text:
which Ian reduces by rationalising
that he does feel benefits.

999.96.text: His dissonance is further reduced in two ways.

1002.62.text:
First, Ian's speech receives huge praise
and applause from other members

1006.76.text:
validating his words and building on his feelings
of acceptance and loyalty to the group.

1011.54.text:
Second, the testimony of other members further
justifies the idea that the tasks have meaning.

1016.62.text:
Other activities train Ian not
to react to provocation.

1019.84.text:
For instance, when being goaded with
insults and jokes by other members.

1023.26.text: Ian learns to disconnect from confrontation.

1026.14.text:
He rationalises that this training
is helping him focus.

1029.12.text: It'll soon be put to other uses.

1031.18.text:
Ian's told of the group's interest
in the betterment of humankind.

1034.60.text: Their aim is 'total freedom for everyone on the planet'.

1037.27.text:
This resonates powerfully with
his own humanitarian concerns.

1040.45.text:
But he's told about critics who want
to sabotage this important work,

1046.88.text:
The group encourages Ian to avoid
mainstream media for this reason.

1052.54.text:
But censorship has now been repackaged as
a sensible precaution against destructive critics.

1058.52.text:
Thee group now controls
all information about the group.

1062.28.text: When later confronted by critics in person

1064.76.text:
Ian automatically disconnects
from them, as he's been trained to do

1068.10.text: blocking out the very folks who could help him.

1070.58.text: In everyday life, Ian feels better, sharper, more confident

1078.32.text:
With the group's courses pitched at kindergarten levels,
in developmental terms, far from being stretched

1087.66.text: Ian's processed straight into the next level.

1089.96.text:
A strange over-ritualised kind
of counseling is introduced

1095.20.text:
to gauge his emotional reaction as he
repeatedly confronts difficult memories.

1099.24.text:
The aim is to nullify all emotional
reaction to past traumas

1102.94.text: until it no longer registers on the apparatus.

1108.04.text:
Sometimes very tiring. But he
frequently emerges feeling lighter.

1112.36.text: The sessions take him further and further into the past

1115.24.text:
until he's not quite sure if he's
dealing with real memories.

1118.46.text: Ian visits his parents. He talks about the group.

1121.74.text:
His father is concerned about
the money Ian's getting through

1124.54.text: and does an internet search on the group.

1126.86.text: He's disturbed at what he reads

1128.78.text: and asked Ian to take a look

1130.62.text: but Ian declines, saying it's all lies.

1133.64.text:
When he tells the group about
his parents' reaction.

1136.34.text: Ian finds himself being interviewed at length

1138.54.text:
with concerns expressed about how
their influence could seriously damage his progress.

1142.78.text: At the end of an exhausting session

1144.78.text:
Ian agrees to only discuss
superficial subjects with his parents.

1148.50.text:
He takes the issue to counselling
to nullify his emotional reaction.

1152.70.text:
The groups' noble aim of total freedom for
everyone on the planet has been repackaged.

1157.52.text:
'Total freedom' now means:
'freedom to do what the group allows'.

1160.82.text: 'Everyone on the planet' now means 'everyone who remains uncritical of the group'.

1165.72.text: Three years and thousands of dollars later

1168.38.text: Ian's completed two levels of counseling.

1171.22.text:
He's also expecting his second child
with his new wife, also a member of the group.

1177.36.text:
He's led into a room and shown a document
that tells him the following information:

1182.08.text:
Millions of years ago, an evil galactic ruler
transported billions of aliens to earth in spaceplanes

1190.46.text: and blew them up with nuclear weapons.

1192.72.text:
As they departed from their bodies,
the alien spirits were then captured in electronic traps

1197.58.text: and subjected to a month-long 3d propaganda movie

1200.52.text:
that implanted false ideas in them
including the world religions.

1203.98.text:
These alien spirits roamed the earth
aimlessly and when humans evolved

1207.96.text: they attached themselves in clusters to their bodies.

1210.62.text:
These alien spirits are what keep humans
from fulfilling their full potential.

1215.54.text:
Ian now experiences perhaps the most
violent dissonance in his life.

1219.34.text: If he rejects the alien story, he's out.

1222.10.text:
And all the time, energy and money
he's invested in the group has been wasted.

1226.28.text: The group's strict policy of shunning dissenters

1228.74.text:
also means the loss of his wife,
his children and all his friends.

1233.29.text: But beyond even these threatening realities

1235.89.text:
is a deep-seated belief that will
keep him under the group's influence

1239.18.text: haemorrhaging money for another two years:

1243.68.text:
To him, the only folks who fall for cons
are gullible, acquiescent, stupid.

1256.66.text: Not because of some personality deficiency.

1259.04.text: But simply because he's a human being

1261.26.text:
who — like all of us — possesses a brain
that's evolved to strive towards consistency.

1266.30.text: In his extreme state of dissonance

1268.38.text:
Ian is led directly into a counselling session
to nullify his emotional reaction.

1278.58.text: A few years ago, a woman wrote to me to tell me

1280.60.text:
she'd once thought I used demonic
psychological techniques in my videos.

1284.34.text:
She'd been in a very controlling
fundamentalist religious group at the time

1287.64.text: and was disturbed to find herself feeling persuaded by some of the atheist counter-arguments I was presenting.

1293.10.text:
She was convinced you satanic mind control
to put her under a spell.

1296.88.text: This was no random rationalisation. Her group had told her this was how the atheists got you.

1301.90.text: And she was terrified it had happened to her.

1304.40.text: To try and break the spell

1305.80.text:
she watched the same videos over and over
to figure out exactly how I'd corrupted her.

1310.26.text:
It was during this process of analysis that she
came to realise the simpler explanation:

1314.82.text: she'd been persuaded by legitimate counter-arguments.

1320.60.text: This woman's story is an illustration of how manipulative groups develop strategies

1324.88.text: to put critics in no-win situations.

1327.68.text: If I fail to persuade, I lose.

1329.66.text:
If I succeed in persuading,
I must be cheating, therefore I lose.

1333.72.text:
Manipulative groups often possess a
wealth of ready-made rationalisations

1337.88.text:
deviously designed so that their members'
cognitive dissonance is resolved in the group's favour.

1342.54.text:
Some of them involve splitting
a single concept into two categories.

1346.18.text:
We saw this with our hypothetical
friend from evil group A

1348.92.text:
whose goodness was invalidated by
repackaging it as a deception.

1352.68.text: Whatever good she did only proved her deceitfulness.

1355.60.text:
Here, goodness was effectively split into
true goodness and false goodness.

1360.04.text: Group A's goodness was always false.
